description:
Ilyonectria robusta is a fungal species that belongs to the genus Ilyonectria, which is a member of the Ascomycota phylum. It is a plant pathogen that primarily infects the roots of various plant species, causing a disease known as black foot disease.

The fungus is characterized by its robust and thick-walled chlamydospores, which are resting structures that help the fungus survive adverse environmental conditions. The hyphae, or the vegetative filamentous structures, of I. robusta are typically dark-colored and have septate (divided by cross-walls) characteristics.

Ilyonectria robusta is known to cause significant damage to the root systems of various plants, including grapevines, fruit trees, and ornamental plants. The infection can lead to reduced plant growth, wilting, and even plant death in severe cases. The fungus can persist in the soil for extended periods, making it a persistent and challenging problem for affected crops and plants.

Understanding the biology and ecology of I. robusta is crucial for developing effective management strategies to mitigate the impact of black foot disease on agricultural and horticultural systems.
